name: Wandering Jew
description: Tradescantia zebrina, commonly known as Wandering Jew, Inch Plant, or Zebra Plant, is a fast-growing, trailing perennial native to Mexico, Central America, and Colombia. It belongs to the Commelinaceae family and features lanceolate to ovate leaves (5-10 cm long, 2-3 cm wide) with a distinctive striped pattern. The upper surface of the leaves is green to purple-green with two longitudinal silver stripes, while the underside is deep purple to burgundy. The leaves are slightly succulent and have a velvety texture. This vining plant features trailing or climbing growth and can reach lengths of 60-90 cm or more. It produces small, three-petaled, pink to purple flowers, though flowering is infrequent in indoor cultivation. Adapted to tropical climates with high humidity, consistent warmth, and filtered light conditions. In its native habitat, it grows as ground cover or on rocky slopes in shaded areas. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant adds natural beauty and greenery to any environment. It's extremely easy to grow and propagate, making it popular among beginners.
careTips: Very easy to grow - ideal for beginners and low-maintenance gardens
Propagates easily in water or soil - stem cuttings root within days
Pinch regularly to encourage bushiness and prevent leggy growth
Can handle some neglect - relatively drought-tolerant once established
Native to Mexico, Central America, Colombia - prefers moderate to warm temperatures (18-27Â°C)
Bright indirect light is best - some direct morning sun enhances leaf colors, too much sun can fade colors
Water when top inch of soil feels dry - allow slight drying between waterings
Well-draining substrate recommended - can tolerate various soil types
Moderate humidity (50-60%) is sufficient, though higher humidity promotes better growth
Feed monthly during growing season with balanced liquid fertilizer at half strength
Non-toxic to humans but can cause mild skin irritation in sensitive individuals
Can become invasive if planted outdoors in warm climates - keep contained
Watch for spider mites and aphids, especially in dry conditions
Leaves may lose variegation in low light - provide adequate light for best colors
Can be grown in hanging baskets, terrariums, or as ground cover
